Headline: Regulating Act
Text: First parliamentary act to supervise East India Company. Created Governor-General position and Council of Four. Established Supreme Court in Calcutta.

Headline: Pitt's India Act
Text: Established dual control of British India by British government and East India Company. Created Board of Control.

Headline: Charter Act
Text: Renewed East India Company's charter for 20 years. Codified laws and regulations. Known as Cornwallis Code.

Headline: Charter Act
Text: Ended East India Company's monopoly on trade with India except for tea and trade with China. Allowed Christian missionaries to enter India.

Headline: Charter Act
Text: Ended East India Company's commercial functions, making it purely administrative. Governor-General of Bengal became Governor-General of India. First Law Commission established.

Headline: Charter Act
Text: Introduced open competition for civil service. Legislative Council functioned like a mini parliament. Company's charter extended without time limit.

Headline: Government of India Act
Text: Transferred control from East India Company to British Crown. Created Secretary of State for India and India Council. Queen Victoria's Proclamation.

Headline: Indian Councils Act
Text: Established new legislative councils. Viceroy could nominate Indians as non-official members.

Headline: Indian Councils Act
Text: Increased number of non-official members in Legislative Councils. Introduced indirect elections.

Headline: Indian Councils Act (Morley-Minto Reforms)
Text: Introduced separate electorates for Muslims. Enlarged legislative councils but maintained official majority.

Headline: Government of India Act (Montagu-Chelmsford Reforms)
Text: Introduced dyarchy in provinces. Divided subjects into transferred and reserved. Extended franchise.

Headline: Government of India Act
Text: Proposed All-India Federation and provincial autonomy. Introduced direct elections. Extended franchise. Remained in force until 1947.

Headline: First Anglo Maratha War
Text: Maratha victory, Treaty of Salbai, British recognized Maratha power

Headline: Second Anglo-Maratha War
Text: British victory. Treaties of Deogaon, Surji-Anjangaon, Rajpurghat. British gained strategic territory.

Headline: Third Anglo-Maratha War
Text: British victory. Peshwaship abolished, Maratha confederacy dissolved. Treaties of Poona, Gwalior, Mandasor.

Headline: First Anglo-Mysore War
Text: Ended with Treaty of Madras. Mutual territory restitution and defensive alliance.

Headline: Second Anglo-Mysore War
Text: Ended with Treaty of Mangalore. Return to pre-war status quo.

Headline: Third Anglo-Mysore War
Text: Ended with Treaty of Seringapatam. Mysore lost half its territory.

Headline: Fourth Anglo-Mysore War
Text: British victory. Fall of Seringapatam, death of Tipu Sultan, Mysore dismembered.

Headline: First Anglo-Sikh War
Text: British victory. Ended with Treaty of Lahore. Sikh Empire weakened.

Headline: Second Anglo-Sikh War
Text: British victory. Annexation of Punjab.

Headline: Battle of Plassey
Text: British East India Company victory over Nawab of Bengal. Foundation of British rule in Bengal.

Headline: First Battle of Panipat
Text: Babur defeated Ibrahim Lodi, marking the beginning of the Mughal Empire in India.

Headline: Second Battle of Panipat
Text: Akbar's forces led by Bairam Khan defeated Hemu, consolidating Mughal rule.

Headline: Third Battle of Panipat
Text: Ahmad Shah Abdali defeated the Marathas, significantly weakening Maratha power in North India.

Headline: Battle of Buxar
Text: British victory over combined forces of Mir Kasim, Nawab of Awadh, and Mughal Emperor. Established British dominance in North India.

Headline: Bombay Session
Text: First INC session. Formation of Indian National Congress.

Headline: Benares Session
Text: Presided by Gokhale. Condemned Bengal partition, supported Swadeshi movement.

Headline: Calcutta Session
Text: Presided by Dadabhai Naoroji. Declared Swaraj as the goal.

Headline: Surat Session
Text: Session suspended due to split between Moderates and Extremists.

Headline: Lucknow Session
Text: Reunion of Moderates and Extremists. Lucknow Pact signed with Muslim League.

Headline: Calcutta Session
Text: Annie Besant became the first woman president of INC.

Headline: Nagpur Session
Text: Endorsed Non-Cooperation Movement. Major organizational changes in Congress.

Headline: Gaya Session
Text: Debate over council entry vs. no-changers. C.R. Das resigned.

Headline: Belgaum Session
Text: Only session presided over by Mahatma Gandhi.

Headline: Lahore Session
Text: Presided by J.L. Nehru. Passed Purna Swaraj (Complete Independence) resolution.

Headline: Karachi Session
Text: Presided by Vallabhbhai Patel. Endorsed Gandhi-Irwin Pact. Adopted resolutions on Fundamental Rights and National Economic Programme.

Headline: Lucknow Session
Text: Presided by J.L. Nehru. Push towards socialist ideas.

Headline: Faizpur Session
Text: First session held in a village.

Headline: Haripura Session
Text: Presided by Subhas Chandra Bose. National Planning Committee set up.

Headline: Tripuri Session
Text: Bose re-elected but resigned due to differences with Gandhi. Rajendra Prasad took over.

Headline: Ramgarh Session
Text: Presided by Maulana Abul Kalam Azad. Decision on Individual Satyagraha.

Headline: Bombay Session (Gowalia Tank)
Text: Passed the Quit India resolution.

Headline: Meerut Session
Text: Presided by J.B. Kripalani. Last session before India's independence.

Headline: Bangabhasha Prakashika Sabha
Text: Formed by Raja Rammohan Roy's associates.

Headline: Landholders' Society
Text: Established to protect zamindari interests, began organized political activity.

Headline: Bengal British India Society
Text: Collected information on Indian conditions.

Headline: British Indian Association
Text: Merger of Landholders' Society and Bengal British India Society. Petitioned for constitutional reforms including popular legislature establishment, executive-judicial function separation, higher officer salary reductions, and abolition of salt, abkari, stamp duties.

Headline: East India Association
Text: Founded in London by Dadabhai Naoroji.

Headline: Indian League
Text: Started by Sisir Kumar Ghosh to promote nationalism.

Headline: Indian Association of Calcutta
Text: Established by Surendranath Banerjee and Ananda Mohan Bose. Most significant pre-Congress organization. Created public opinion on political issues, unified Indians, protested civil service age restrictions.

Headline: First All-India Conference
Text: Hosted by Indian Association of Calcutta, precursor to Indian National Congress.

Headline: Poona Sarvajanik Sabha
Text: Founded by Mahadev Govind Ranade and Ganesh Vasudeo Joshi. Established arbitration courts (nyayan sabha) for private settlement of civil disputes, organised famine relief in Deccan region.

Headline: Madras Mahajan Sabha
Text: Formed by Viraraghavachariar, B Aiyer, and P Ananda Charlu. Aimed at national liberation, tax reduction, spending cuts, fundamental rights.

Headline: Bombay Presidency Association
Text: Established by Badruddin Tyabji, Pherozeshah Mehta, and K.T. Telang.

Headline: Announcement of Bengal Partition
Text: Lord Curzon formally announced the decision to partition Bengal.

Headline: Partition of Bengal
Text: Lord Curzon partitioned Bengal into East Bengal (with Assam) and West Bengal (with Bihar and Orissa). Created on religious and administrative grounds.

Headline: Swadeshi Movement
Text: Mass protest movement against Bengal partition. Led to boycott of British goods and promotion of indigenous products.

Headline: Annulment of Bengal Partition
Text: King George V announced the annulment of Bengal Partition at Delhi Durbar. Bengal reunited in 1912.

Headline: Partition of Bengal
Text: Bengal was divided into West Bengal (India) and East Bengal (East Pakistan, later Bangladesh). Part of the larger partition of India.

Headline: Moderate Phase of Indian National Congress
Text: Early Congress leaders like Dadabhai Naoroji, Gopal Krishna Gokhale, and Surendranath Banerjee advocated constitutional methods, petitions, and prayers. They believed in gradual reforms and cooperation with the British government.

Headline: Indian National Conference
Text: Founded by Surendranath Banerjee, precursor to Indian National Congress. Represented moderate approach to political reform.

Headline: Poverty and Un-British Rule in India
Text: Dadabhai Naoroji published this influential work exposing the economic exploitation of India, introducing the "Drain of Wealth" theory.

Headline: Extremist Phase of Indian National Congress
Text: Leaders like Bal Gangadhar Tilak, Bipin Chandra Pal, and Lala Lajpat Rai advocated for aggressive methods, self-reliance, and complete independence from British rule.

Headline: Kesari Sedition Case
Text: Bal Gangadhar Tilak was imprisoned for sedition after publishing articles in his newspaper Kesari supporting revolutionary activities (Twice: In 1908 sentenced to 6 years in prison)

Headline: Formation of Abhinav Bharat
Text: Secret society formed by V.D. Savarkar to organize armed resistance against British rule.

Headline: Home Rule League (Tilak)
Text: Founded by Bal Gangadhar Tilak in Pune, advocated self-government for India.

Headline: Home Rule League (Besant)
Text: Founded by Annie Besant in Madras, worked parallel to Tilak's league with similar goals.

Headline: Ghadar Party
Text: Revolutionary movement founded by Punjabi Indians in the United States and Canada, aimed at overthrowing British rule in India.

Headline: Hindustan Socialist Republican Association
Text: Revolutionary organization founded by Bhagat Singh, Sukhdev, and others to fight for India's independence through revolutionary means.

Headline: Kakori Conspiracy
Text: Train robbery carried out by Hindustan Republican Association to fund their revolutionary activities.

Headline: Central Assembly Bombing
Text: Bhagat Singh and Batukeshwar Dutt threw bombs in the Central Legislative Assembly to protest against repressive laws.

Headline: Alipore Bomb Case
Text: Case against Aurobindo Ghosh, his brother Barindra Ghosh, and 36 others following a bomb attack on a carriage carrying Magistrate Douglas Kingsford. Resulted in the death of revolutionary Prafulla Chaki and imprisonment of many others.

Headline: Delhi Conspiracy Case
Text: Conspiracy to assassinate Viceroy Lord Hardinge during his state entry into Delhi. A bomb was thrown at Lord Hardinge's elephant procession, injuring him but not fatally.

Headline: Ghadar Conspiracy Case
Text: Conspiracy by the Ghadar Party to initiate a pan-Indian mutiny in the British Indian Army. The plot was uncovered and suppressed through a series of trials.

Headline: Banaras Conspiracy Case
Text: Conspiracy involving revolutionaries from Bengal and Punjab to smuggle arms and incite rebellion. Led to the arrest of several revolutionaries including Sachindra Nath Sanyal.

Headline: Kanpur Conspiracy Case
Text: Case against communist leaders including M.N. Roy, S.A. Dange, Muzaffar Ahmed, and Shaukat Usmani for conspiring to overthrow the British government. First major communist conspiracy case in India.

Headline: Kakori Conspiracy Case
Text: Train robbery carried out by Hindustan Republican Association to fund revolutionary activities. Led to the arrest and execution of Ram Prasad Bismil, Ashfaqulla Khan, Roshan Singh, and Rajendra Lahiri.

Headline: Lahore Conspiracy Case
Text: Case against Bhagat Singh, Sukhdev, Rajguru, and others for the murder of British police officer J.P. Saunders and the Assembly Bomb Case. Resulted in the execution of Bhagat Singh, Sukhdev, and Rajguru.

Headline: Meerut Conspiracy Case
Text: Case against 31 communist and trade union leaders for organizing workers and planning to overthrow the British government. Trial lasted four years and brought communism to public attention in India.

Headline: Chittagong Armoury Raid Case
Text: Case against Surya Sen and his associates for raiding the police armoury in Chittagong. Surya Sen was arrested in 1933 and executed in 1934.

Headline: Peshawar Conspiracy Cases
Text: Series of cases against members of the Communist Party and Muhajirs who had returned from Soviet Russia. Aimed at suppressing communist activities in India.

Headline: Hunter Commission (Education)
Text: Appointed under Sir William Hunter to review the progress of education in India following Wood's Dispatch of 1854. Recommended expansion of primary education and greater private control of secondary schools.

Headline: Welby Commission
Text: Royal Commission on Indian Expenditure chaired by Lord Welby. Examined the apportionment of charges between Britain and India. Dadabhai Naoroji presented evidence on the economic drain from India.

Headline: Fowler Committee
Text: Committee on Indian Currency chaired by Sir Henry Fowler. Recommended adoption of the Gold Exchange Standard and fixing the rupee to sterling at 1s. 4d.

Headline: Macdonell Commission
Text: Famine Commission headed by Sir Antony Macdonell to investigate the famines of 1896-97 and 1899-1900. Recommended agricultural improvements and famine relief measures.

Headline: Fraser Commission
Text: Police Commission headed by Sir Andrew Fraser. Recommended reorganization of the police force, improved training, and better pay for police officers.

Headline: Raleigh Commission
Text: University Commission headed by Sir Thomas Raleigh. Led to the Indian Universities Act of 1904, which increased government control over universities.

Headline: Hunter Commission (Jallianwala Bagh)
Text: Committee headed by Lord William Hunter to investigate the Jallianwala Bagh Massacre. Condemned General Dyer's actions but did not recommend legal proceedings against him.

Headline: Lee Commission
Text: Royal Commission on the Public Services in India chaired by Lord Lee. Recommended increased Indianization of civil services with recruitment of Indians to 40% of ICS posts initially, increasing to 50% over 15 years.

Headline: Muddiman Committee
Text: Committee headed by Sir Alexander Muddiman to examine the working of the 1919 Government of India Act. Majority report suggested minor reforms while minority report demanded major constitutional changes.

Headline: Hilton Young Commission
Text: Royal Commission on Indian Currency and Finance chaired by Sir Edward Hilton Young. Recommended establishment of the Reserve Bank of India as a central bank free from political influence.

Headline: Linlithgow Commission
Text: Royal Commission on Agriculture in India headed by Lord Linlithgow. Recommended establishment of the Imperial Council of Agricultural Research (later ICAR) and agricultural research institutes.

Headline: Simon Commission
Text: Statutory Commission headed by Sir John Simon to review the working of the Government of India Act 1919. All-white membership led to its boycott by Indians. Recommendations formed basis for Government of India Act 1935.

Headline: Butler Committee
Text: Indian States Committee headed by Sir Harcourt Butler to clarify the relationship between Princely States and the British Crown. Affirmed that Paramountcy was supreme and could not be transferred to an Indian government.

Headline: Whitley Commission
Text: Royal Commission on Labour in India headed by John Henry Whitley. Investigated industrial labor conditions and recommended improved working conditions, minimum wages, and right to form unions.

Headline: Hartog Committee
Text: Committee headed by Sir Philip Hartog to review the growth of education in British India. Criticized the quality of primary education and recommended focus on quality rather than quantity.

Headline: Warren Hastings
Text: First Governor-General of Bengal. Established civil service, judiciary, and revenue collection systems. Fought against Marathas and Mysore. Impeached after return to England but acquitted.

Headline: Lord Cornwallis
Text: Governor-General who introduced Permanent Settlement in Bengal (1793). Reorganized civil services and judiciary. Separated revenue collection from judicial functions. Defeated Tipu Sultan in Third Anglo-Mysore War.

Headline: Lord Wellesley
Text: Governor-General who implemented Subsidiary Alliance system to expand British control. Defeated Tipu Sultan in Fourth Anglo-Mysore War. Founded Fort William College for training civil servants.

Headline: Lord William Bentinck
Text: Governor-General who abolished Sati (1829) and suppressed Thuggee. Introduced English education through English Education Act (1835). Reformed revenue systems in Madras and Bombay. Annexed Mysore.

Headline: Lord Dalhousie
Text: Governor-General who implemented Doctrine of Lapse, annexing states without direct heirs. Introduced railways, telegraph, postal system, and Public Works Department. Annexed Punjab, Lower Burma, and several princely states.

Headline: Lord Canning
Text: Last Governor-General and first Viceroy of India. Handled the Revolt of 1857. Introduced Indian Penal Code. Queen's Proclamation transferred power from East India Company to British Crown.

Headline: Lord Lytton
Text: Viceroy who organized Delhi Durbar (1877) to proclaim Queen Victoria as Empress of India. Introduced Vernacular Press Act (1878) and Arms Act (1878). Faced severe famine (1876-78).

Headline: Lord Ripon
Text: Liberal Viceroy who introduced local self-government and repealed Vernacular Press Act. Attempted to pass Ilbert Bill for judicial equality but faced strong European opposition. First factory legislation (1881).

Headline: Lord Curzon
Text: Viceroy who partitioned Bengal (1905), created North-West Frontier Province, and passed Ancient Monuments Preservation Act. Reformed police, education, and irrigation. Established Agricultural Research Institute at Pusa.

Headline: Lord Minto II
Text: Viceroy who worked with Secretary of State Morley to introduce Morley-Minto Reforms (1909). Dealt with growing nationalist movement and revolutionary terrorism. Established Imperial Council of Agricultural Research.

Headline: Lord Hardinge
Text: Viceroy during Delhi Durbar (1911) when King George V announced annulment of Bengal Partition and transfer of capital from Calcutta to Delhi. Survived assassination attempt in 1912.

Headline: Lord Chelmsford
Text: Viceroy who worked with Secretary of State Montagu to introduce Montagu-Chelmsford Reforms (1919). Faced Jallianwala Bagh Massacre (1919) and Non-Cooperation Movement. Established Rowlatt Act.

Headline: Lord Reading
Text: Viceroy who dealt with Non-Cooperation Movement and imprisoned Gandhi. Repealed Rowlatt Act and reduced salt tax. Appointed Royal Commission on Superior Civil Services (Lee Commission).

Headline: Lord Irwin
Text: Viceroy who appointed Simon Commission (1927). Issued Irwin Declaration (1929) promising dominion status for India. Signed Gandhi-Irwin Pact (1931) ending Civil Disobedience Movement.

Headline: Lord Willingdon
Text: Viceroy who faced renewed Civil Disobedience Movement and imprisoned Gandhi and other Congress leaders. Implemented Government of India Act 1935. Opened new capital New Delhi.

Headline: Lord Linlithgow
Text: Longest-serving Viceroy who declared India at war with Germany without consulting Indian leaders. Faced Quit India Movement (1942). Offered Cripps Proposal (1942) which was rejected by Congress.

Headline: Lord Wavell
Text: Viceroy who released Congress leaders and organized Simla Conference (1945). Proposed Cabinet Mission Plan (1946). Dealt with post-war political negotiations and communal violence.

Headline: Lord Mountbatten
Text: Last Viceroy who implemented partition and independence of India and Pakistan. Prepared Mountbatten Plan for transfer of power. Became first Governor-General of independent India.

Headline: General Dyer
Text: British military officer responsible for Jallianwala Bagh Massacre (April 13, 1919) in Amritsar, where troops fired on unarmed civilians, killing hundreds. Later removed from duty but praised by many in Britain.

Headline: Lord Kitchener
Text: Commander-in-Chief of India who reorganized Indian Army. Clashed with Viceroy Curzon over military administration, leading to Curzon's resignation. Established Staff College at Quetta.

Headline: Sir Thomas Munro
Text: Governor of Madras who introduced Ryotwari System of land revenue. Advocated direct settlement with cultivators rather than zamindars. Promoted Indian participation in administration.

Headline: Sir Charles Wood
Text: Secretary of State for India who issued Wood's Dispatch (1854), known as "Magna Carta of English Education in India." Established modern educational system with universities in Calcutta, Bombay, and Madras.

Headline: Sir John Lawrence
Text: Chief Commissioner of Punjab during 1857 Revolt who maintained control of the region. Later became Viceroy (1864-69). Known for administrative reforms and public works.

Headline: Sir Charles Napier
Text: British general who conquered Sindh in 1843 and became its first Governor. Famously sent message "Peccavi" (Latin for "I have sinned") after conquest.
